node.text: As a student of racism, I am always learning about its different manifestations. And what I’ve learned over the years, in engaging with folks from multiple communities, is that people have their own languages and terms, have their own understanding of seeing the world and seeing themselves. To create bridges, we must learn to see racism in all its forms. And that's what I am hoping to do with #BeAntiracist.

node.title: CBS This Morning - Be Antiracist Podcast

node.text:
I'm glad to announce I've officially joined the podcasting community. Shout out to all the podcasters and podcast listeners. To kick off #BeAntiracist with @PushkinPods, I sat down with Pushkin's co-founder @malcolmgladwell. We discussed the human capacity to change and grow. And, as fellow authors, we discussed words and their meaning, particularly the word "racist," and much more.

Subscribe and listen now. Link in bio.

node.title: Be Antiracist: Bridging Divisions (with Malcolm Gladwell)

node.text:
My action podcast #BeAntiracist premieres on 6/9. Thinking with a special guest, each week we get into the weeds on a different form of racism--and offer precise and practical solutions so we can all take action. Here’s a preview of #BeAntiracist.

Click linktree in my bio to subscribe.

node.text: I was so glad to join with other authors to express my admiration, appreciation, and gratitude to teachers everywhere. We have so much to THANK YOU for this year, as we do every year. #teacherappreciationweek🍎

node.text:
Army Lt. Nazario was driving his new car home. He was pulled over for driving while Black, and when he “didn’t comply” with the racist police officers, he was pepper sprayed and arrested.

I can’t tell you how many Black people in history were whipped, beaten, or lynched because they “didn’t comply” and then blamed for their own injuries and deaths since they “didn’t comply.” 

Racial violence has changed clothes over the years but still demands what will never come: Black compliance to racism and White supremacy.

node.text: The other day, @binajv and I went on @morningjoe to discuss @the_emancipator, an independent media platform founded by @antiracismctr and @globeopinion that will be likely be launched later in the year. We are searching for co-editors-in-chief to lead @the_emancipator. A link to the project is in my bio.

node.text:
“The Atlanta shooter blamed a specific race of people for his problems, and then murdered them because of it. If that’s not racism, then the word has no meaning.” —Repost from @thedailyshow.

And that's the point. Efforts to strip the word "democracy" of its meaning are mirroring efforts to strip the word "racism" of its meaning.

When democracy loses its meaning, no one will know when it dies. When racism loses its meaning, no one will know when it lives.

"We brought in so many stories and so many perspectives, and those stories were bite-sized so people could wrap their heads around them."

Thank you @capehartj for discussing #400Souls with me and @keishanblain on your show. 🙏🏾

node.text: FOUR HUNDRED SOULS features 10 poems, one concluding every 40-year part. The third part, from 1699 to 1739, ends with a powerful poem by Morgan Parker. Here is @morganapple0 reading, “Before Revolution” @barnesandnoble. #400Souls

node.text:
When I was a child in Jamaica, Queens, I could see Black neighbors, Latinx neighbors, Asian neighbors, and a handful of White neighbors. But I could not “see” Native neighbors, though they were there. We were taught the racist trope of the “vanishing Indian.” It's a trope as misleading as the “happy slave.” 

Today on #BeAntiracist, National Book Award finalist David Treuer (@suavejohnray) joins me for a fascinating conversation and learning experience, reflecting on Native history and cultures; their stories and lives. Treuer is the author of The Heartbeat of Wounded Knee, a sweeping history and counter-narrative of Native American life from the 1890 Wounded Knee massacre to the present. We discussed settler colonialism and Treuer's recent call for the U.S. government to return the National Parks to the tribes. 

Take a listen at the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ibram X. Kendi on August 04, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'FOR WOMEN WHO GIVE EVE RYTHING, WE GIVE OUR TIME. ARE YOU IN? #40x40'.

node.text:
To celebrate the 40th birthday of my friend Meghan Markle, The Duchess of Sussex, I’m donating 40 minutes of mentorship to a woman reentering the workforce. About 1.8 million fewer women were employed in May 2021 compared to February 2020, before COVID-19 swept across the country. Let’s support women as they reenter the workforce. Will you join me? #40x40 #CompassionInAction

For more information, see the linktree in my bio.

node.text: Happy Born Day to one of the greatest, James Baldwin. Thank you for critiquing out of love.

node.text: A word.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Ibram X. Kendi on July 28, 2021 tagging @pushkinpods, and @project.nia. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '990o BE ANTIRACIST WITH IBRAM X. KENDI'.

node.text:
The “criminal legal system focuses on individuals who have done harm; while abolitionists consider the larger social, economic, and political context in which the harm occurs.”

These are the words of one of America’s most influential abolitionists and today’s guest on #BeAntiracist, Mariame Kaba. She is the author of the bestseller, WE DO THIS 'TIL WE FREE US and the founder of @project.nia, an organization that aims “to end the incarceration of children and young adults by promoting restorative and transformative justice practices.”

While other Americans are committed to feeling secure, Kaba is committed to being safe. We discussed why she doesn’t believe a society of mass surveillance, policing, punishment, and incarceration will ever allow us to build a safe society—and what will. Listen now at the link in my bio.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Ibram X. Kendi on July 28, 2021 tagging @pushkinpods, and @project.nia. May be an image of 1 person and text that says '990o BE ANTIRACIST WITH IBRAM X. KENDI'.

Photo by Ibram X. Kendi on July 28, 2021. May be an image of text that says 'BE ANTIRACIST WITH IBRAMX KENDI SEASON 1 PRISON & POLICE ABOLITION: FINDING TRUE SAFETY "Stop pretending you don't know about the violence of policing and the violence of prisons... People know and we can't pretend constantly to be surprised and just say, 'Reform is the answer when you know it hasn't done that." MARIAME KABA-'.
Photo by Ibram X. Kendi on July 25, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 1 person, child and indoor.

node.text:
One of the main architects, one of the leading visionaries for a multiracial democracy in this country has passed on into eternity. 

Rest in the love of all those Americans fighting for a multiracial democracy today. Rest in our love, Robert P. Moses.

Photo by Ibram X. Kendi on July 25, 2021. May be a black-and-white image of 2 people and text that says 'WANTED BoB MOSES DEAD OR ALIVE Negro man. Mid twenties. Average height and weight. Wears glasses. Sometimes wears overalls. He is the leader of a group of civil rights activists working in Mississippi. The KKK will pay a reward for information on his whereabouts or proof of his death.'.

node.text: What it means to be antiracist? In one minute. From a recent interview at @nytimes.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo by Ibram X. Kendi on July 22, 2021. May be an image of 3 people and text.

node.text: Thank you @kehindeandrews, for featuring @KeishaNBlain and I—and our book #400Souls—as part a larger discussion of recent academic efforts to draw from the evidence and share the full and complicated story of Western history.

node.accessibility_caption: Photo shared by Ibram X. Kendi on July 21, 2021 tagging @juliancastrotx, and @pushkinpods. May be an image of 1 person and text that says 'BE ANTIRACIST PENIE WITH IBRAM X. KENDI'.

node.text:
To talk about the unbreakable bond between antiracism and immigrant rights in America, I’m joined this week on my action podcast #BeAntiracist by the former Secretary of Housing and Urban Development, @juliancastrotx. We discussed the essential need for an antiracist immigration policy that puts people first.

Listen now at the link in my bio.
